Homage to Bodhisattva Hidden Body I take refuge in the immeasurable and boundless great bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas in the worlds of the ten directions.
Respectfully pay homage to all the sages and saints of the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
Having paid homage to the Three Jewels, I will next repent.
Disciples!
As explained above, I have already repented of the light and heavy offenses committed against the Three Jewels. The remaining offenses, I will now repent of in order.
The Buddha said in the sÅ«tra:
There are two kinds of strong people:
First, those who do not commit offenses;
Second, those who are able to repent after committing them.
It is also said:
There are two kinds of pure dharmas that can eliminate the various obstacles for sentient beings:
First, shame;
Second, remorse.
Those who have shame do not commit evil themselves, and those who have remorse do not allow others to commit them. Those who have shame and remorse can be called people.
If one has neither shame nor remorse, one is no different from the beasts.
Those who have shame are ashamed before the heavens, and those who have remorse confess the offenses they have committed to others.
Therefore, disciples!
Today, with utmost sincerity, I am ashamed and remorseful, and take refuge in the Buddha.

Homage to the Buddha RatnapÄda in the east, homage to the Buddha ParamayajÃ±a in the south, homage to the Buddha Asamavikrama in the west, homage to the Buddha DharmarÅ«pa in the north, homage to the Buddha Brahmavardhana in the southeast, homage to the Buddha Åšakravajra in the southwest, homage to the Buddha SamantÄvabhÄsa in the northwest, homage to the Buddha MahÄÅ›rÄ«ghoá¹£a in the northeast, homage to the Buddha SÄgaramati in the nadir, homage to the Buddha ViÅ›uddhaprajÃ±Äguá¹‡arÄÅ›i in the zenith. We take refuge in the Three Jewels of the ten directions and the entire Dharma realm.
Disciples!

From beginningless time until now, we have either believed in wrong and inverted views, slaughtered sentient beings, and offered them to demons, goblins, and ghosts, hoping to prolong our lives but ultimately being unable to achieve it.
Or we have falsely claimed to have seen ghosts and pretended to speak the words of spirits.
Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless. Today we feel ashamed and confess them.
Moreover, disciples!

From beginningless time until today, we have been arrogant and conceited, either relying on our family background to look down on everyone, using our status to deceive the humble and our strength to oppress the weak, or relying on our wealth to look down on the poor and our official position to look down on those below us.
We have drunk alcohol, caused fights and chaos, not avoiding relatives or strangers, being intoxicated all day long and not recognizing superiors or inferiors.
Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless.
Today, we sincerely confess and repent.

We have been greedy, lazy, ignorant of shame, greedy for food and drink, not caring about hardship, drinking alcohol, eating meat, singing and dancing, without any sense of moderation or knowing when to rest.

We have eaten raw fish, drunk the five pungent things, and polluted scriptures and images, pushing aside the pure assembly, indulging our minds and unrestrained, not knowing the ultimate principle, neglecting good people and befriending bad friends.

Or being arrogant, deceitful, stubborn, and self-willed, rough and rude, not understanding human feelings, judging oneself right and others wrong, being able to do things oneself but hating others, seeing others' faults and attacking them, fabricating words and phrases in the hope of gaining something by chance.
Such offenses are innumerable and boundless. Today, with utmost sincerity, I take refuge and repent.
Or, when it comes to money, one is not generous, lacking integrity and shame, butchering meat, selling alcohol, deceiving others to make a living.
Or, calculating the profits and losses of investments, selling time and days, hoarding and being stingy, greedily seeking without satiation, receiving offerings from others without feeling ashamed.
Or, lacking precepts and conduct, empty-handed accepting donations of faith, beating slaves, whipping servants, and driving them without asking about hunger or thirst, not knowing about cold or heat.
Or, dismantling bridges and roads, blocking and cutting off passage.
Such offenses are innumerable and boundless. Today, with utmost sincerity, I take refuge and repent.

Or, being unrestrained and heedless, we play games like go, chess, and backgammon, gather in groups, drink alcohol, eat meat, criticize each other, engage in meaningless conversations, and discuss worldly affairs from month to year, wasting our days in vain.

We do not practice meditation or recitation in the first, middle, and last parts of the night, are lazy and indolent, lie down all day, do not attend to the six mindfulnesses, give rise to jealousy upon seeing others' superior matters, harbor malicious thoughts, and give rise to afflictions, causing the fierce winds of evil to blow, the fire of evil fuel to blaze, and have no rest.
The slightest wholesome karma of the three karmas is all burned together. When wholesome dharmas are exhausted, one becomes an icchantika, falls into the fire hell, and has no chance of escape.
Therefore, disciples!
Today, with utmost sincerity, we bow our heads before the assembly of Buddhas and sages in the ten directions, repenting of all the various offenses we have committed above.

Whether light or heavy, coarse or fine, done by oneself, instructed to others, rejoiced in, or forced by power, up to praising the practice of evil dharmas, today I confess and repent with utmost sincerity, wishing for all to be extinguished.

May the disciples, relying on the merit born from repenting of all evils, wish to be kind and harmonious, loyal and filial, humble and self-abasing, knowing shame and disgrace, inquiring first with a sincere mind, being virtuous and sincere, pure and righteous, avoiding evil friends and always encountering good conditions, restraining the six sense faculties and respectfully protecting the three karmas, enduring hardship and suffering without a retreating mind, establishing the resolve for enlightenment and bearing the burden for sentient beings.
The Sutra of the Questions and Answers of the Mahayana Lotus Treasure-Reaching Monk on Retribution, Treasure-Reaching Previously Entered the Fire Rice Hell.

In that hell, flowing fire pours down to burn the sinners. There is also rice in the fire, which is also burning. These sinners raise their hands to grab the rice, and it burns their hands, causing them to rot.
Baota asked the horse-headed rakshasa:
What sins did these monks commit to suffer such retribution?
The horse-headed rakshasa replied:
Monks!
These monks used impure hands to touch the pure food of the Sangha. For this reason, they fell into this hell.
When Baota heard this, he wept sorrowfully and left.Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Buddhist Scriptures, Scroll 25
